title: Abysmally low LP gains
body:
I have 19 more wins than I do losses, and I play consistently, yet I constantly only gain 17 and 16 LP, and constantly lose 17-21 LP when I lose.
I have no idea why.
Why does the game want me to drop in rank when I win more than I lose?

My MMR from OP.GG
http://i.imgur.com/pWyZTwd.png

replies.body:
Hello FunboxTha3rd!

First, before we talk about anything else, I want to be clear that OP.GG is a 3rd party site and may not always have the most reliable information.  Especially when it comes to MMR, you need to take these numbers with a huge grain of salt, as they are simply not always accurate (For example, your real MMR is not what OP.GG says it is).

What your screenshot is saying is correct though; there is an expected MMR for each Division/Tier in ranked.  If your MMR is lower than this expected MMR, the system will award you less LP per win, and give more LP per loss due to it trying to challenge you that this is the division you belong in.  Otherwise, if you keep losing, the system will demote you to a division that has an expected MMR closer to your MMR. [You can learn more about this here.](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/204010760-Ranked-Play-FAQ#h2q4)

At the end of the day, keep playing!  As long as you keep winning more than you lose, your MMR will rise to the point that the system will start evening out your earned/lost LP per game.

Let me know if you have any other questions!

>At the end of the day, keep playing! As long as you keep winning more than you lose, your MMR will rise to the point that the system will start evening out your earned/lost LP per game.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't think is a true statement. Your MMR gains/losses depend on what side you're playing. Blue is the lower average MMR team, purple is higher. If you win as purple you're "expected" to win and gain less MMR than you would have if you were blue. Likewise, a loss on blue causes you to lose more MMR. Assuming that premise is correct, you could win more than 50% of your games and go down in MMR:

Let X be the amount of MMR you gain from winning on purple where X > 0

Let X+ε be the amount of MMR you lose from losing on purple where ε > 0

Let N be the number of games played where N > 0 and N is odd.

Let W be the number of wins on purple and L be the number of losses on purple where:

W = N / 2 + 0.5

L = N / 2 - 0.5

Thus the MMR gained is:

δMMR = W*X - L*(X+ε)

δMMR = (N/2+0.5)*X - (N/2-0.5)*(X+ε)

δMMR = X + 0.5ε - N*ε/2

Thus the following statement is true:

2X/ε + ε < N implies δMMR < 0

Since X and ε are constant while N is not, the above statement will eventually be true for sufficiently large values of N. **This means that you are winning more than half your games and going down in MMR**.

---

But wait, that's an unrealistic scenario! You don't really play all purple games so that doesn't work. Except the argument can be extended to every day scenarios. Here's that proof:

Let X be the amount of MMR you gain from winning on purple and lose from losing on blue where X > 0

Let X+ε be the amount of MMR you lose from losing on purple and gain from winning on blue where ε > 0

Let Wp be the number of wins on purple

Let Lp be the number of losses on purple

Let Wb be the number of wins on blue

Let Lb be the number of losses on blue

Thus the MMR gained is:

δMMR = Wp*X - Lp*(x+ε) + Wb*(x+ε) - Lb*(X)

Now let's say Wp = Lp = Wb = Lb. This is saying you have a perfectly even distribution of wins and losses among the sides. Now let's say you play one more game on purple and win it. Thus:

Wp - 1 = Lp = Wb = Lb

At this point:

* You've won more games than you've lost
* δMMR = X

What we want to do now is keep the total number of games won and lost the same while reducing δMMR. We can do this by either taking a win out of blue side wins (Wb) and into purple side wins (Wp) or by taking a loss out blue side losses (Lb) and into purple side losses (Lp). Doing so will subtract ε from δMMR, represented by:

δMMR = X - ε*S where S is the number of times you've "shifted" a win or loss.

X/ε < S implies δMMR < 0

So we just need to do this enough times so that X/ε < S. But we have to be certain that we actually can do this enough times:

In the scenario where Wb = 0 or Lb = 0 we can increment all counters by 1. The MMR gained by the purple side win will cancel with the blue side loss, and the MMR gained by the blue side win will cancel with the purple side loss. As a result of the 4 new games your MMR hasn't changed. Now we can shift the distribution of wins, hit 0, add 4 more games, rinse and repeat.

Again, this means that **your MMR gains are negative, even though you've still won more games than lost.**

Why does this have thumbs up? Not that it's not informative; it just doesn't address the original post at all, nor does the original poster imply that he didn't know any of this already in any way. The response gives a very automated feel past paragraph 2.
So I'm stuck with playing with players that lack skill. Granting me abysmal LP and losing a lot of LP? No challenge one bit.

it takes quite a while for MMR to rise... I know this first hand. All you can do is play your best, as you improve so will your chances to win and therefore your MMR will rise.

Some additional advice from an extremely seasoned veteran of the current MMR system... don't even think about MMR. You cant see it, you cant calculate it, and it is pointless to try (trust me, I have tried). The best way to go about it is out of sight out of mind. The less you think about MMR and even LP gains and losses the better you will do.

Things to keep in mind as you play:
- There will always be 1 team that wins and 1 that losses, sometimes your team wins and sometimes it doesn't. just how it is.
- Try not to compare yourself to others, the more you do the more frustrated you will get.
- Play the way you like to play, but still be flexible. try to have a few different champs that fill each of the roles a team needs so when the team needs something you are ready to fill in the gap.
- Don't try to play like the pros. learn what you can from replays and streams but don't try to imitate them, it usually just ends badly. the pros are pros and you are you. do what you are good at, not what they are good at.
- And the most important tip i can give is HAVE FUN! if you are not having fun playing ranked, stop. play a different game mode, take a break, do what you have to do so that you can enjoy the game, not get angry at it.

On a side note, those gains and losses are pretty common once you have "normalized" (played enough ranked games for the system to be able to evaluate what your current skill level is). also those websites that say they can tell you your MMR are all full of crap, do not even bother going to them.

maybe 19 wins is not enough for your super awesome potential :D
keep going
